Solution

HTML Compiler

Angular's HTML compiler allows the developer to teach the browser new HTML syntax.

It allows you to attach behavior to any HTML element or attribute and even create new HTML elements or attributes with custom behavior.

Angular calls these behavior extensions directives.

Angular comes pre-bundled with common directives which are useful for building any app.

Later, we'll learn how to create our own directives that are custom to our application.

So what does a directive look like?



<div ng-bind="exp"></div>

Now, back to the compiler

The

compiler is an Angular service which traverses the DOM looking for directives.

The compilation process happens in two phases.

Link

Traverse the DOM and collect all of the directives.

Compile

Combine the directives with a scope and produce a live view. Any changes in the scope model are reflected in the view, and any user interactions with the view are reflected in the scope model.

This makes the scope model the single source of truth.

Scope

Scope is an object that refers to the application model. It is an execution context for expressions.

Scopes are arranged in hierarchical structure which mimic the DOM structure of the application.

We'll discuss directives and scope in detail later.

Let's see the HTML compiler in action

ng-init evaluates a JavaScript expression on scope.

ng-bind takes a variable on scope and sets the content of the element to it.



<div ng-init="myVar = 1 + 2;">
  <p ng-bind="myVar"></p>
</div>

What will the DOM look like after compilation and linking?


<div ng-init="myVar = 1 + 2;">
  <p ng-bind="myVar">3</p>
</div>

Instead of using ng-bind, we can use the shorthand {{ }}

The linker will execute the expression inside {{ }} on scope and replace it with the result.


<div ng-init="myVar = 1 + 2;">
  <p>{{myVar}}{{myVar + 1}}</p>
</div>

What will the DOM look like after compilation and linking?


<div ng-init="myVar = 1 + 2;">
  <p>34</p>
</div>

Modules

You can think of a module as a container for the different parts of your app.

Most applications have a main method that instantiates and wires together the different parts of the application.

Angular apps don't have a main method. Instead, modules declaratively specify how an application should be bootstrapped.

There are several advantages to this approach

  • The declarative process is easier to understand.
  • You can package code as reusable modules.
  • The modules can be loaded in any order because modules delay execution.

The AngularJS team recommends you break up modules in the following way

  • A module for each feature
  • A module for each reusable component
  • An application level module which depends on the above modules and contains any initialization code

What does a module look like?

The code below creates a new module named 'app'



angular.module('app', []);

Modules can list other modules as their dependencies.

Depending on a module implies that the required module needs to be loaded before the requiring module is loaded.

Each module will only be loaded once, even if multiple other modules require it.

Below is an example of how to specify a module dependency.



angular.module('app', [
  'feature1'
]);

angular.module('feature1', [
  'feature1.1'
]);

angular.module('feature1.1', []);

Notice the order. Will this work?

Yes.

Because modules do nothing at load time, they can be loaded into the VM in any order and thus script loaders can take advantage of this property and parallelize the loading process.

Dependency

Injection

Dependency Injection (DI) is a software design pattern that deals with how code gets hold of its dependencies.

The Angular injector subsystem is in charge of service instantiation, resolution of dependencies, and provision of dependencies to components as requested.

The simplest way to get hold of the dependencies is to assume that the function parameter names are the names of the dependencies.

Given a function, the injector can infer the names of the service to inject by examining the function declaration and extracting the parameter names.

The example below shows how to specify that $scope and myService need to be injected into the function.



  function($scope, myService) {
  
  }

The argument-based DI method doesn't always work; we'll elaborate on the reason in Lecture 12.

Because of this complication, we can also use the array method for specifying dependencies.

Below is the array method for injecting dependencies.



  [
    '$scope',
    'myService',
    function($scope, myService) {
    
    }
  ]

If we change the name of the function arguments, will DI still work?

Yes.

When using the array method, the injector service will use the strings as the dependency names and inject those dependencies into the function arguments in order.

Where can you use dependency injection in Angular?

DI is pervasive throughout Angular. You can use it in controllers, services, directives, filters, animations, and run and config blocks (all of which we will discuss later)

Controllers

In Angular, a controller is a JavaScript constructor function that is used to augment the Angular Scope.

You can create controllers on a module. The first argument is the controller name, and the second is the constructor function.



angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('AppController',
    function() {
    
    }
  );

You should use controllers to

  • Set up the initial state of the scope.
  • Add behavior to the scope.

You should not use controllers to

  • Manipulate DOM
  • Share code or state across controllers
  • Manage the life-cycle of other components
  • Format input
  • Format output

We'll talk about other components that accomplish these functions later.

In general, a controller shouldn't try to do too much.

It should contain only the business logic needed for a single view.

When creating a controller you can inject the new scope as well as other dependencies.



angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('AppController',
    function($scope, $interval) {
    
    }
  );

You can associate controllers with scope objects implicitly via the ngController directive.

Controller


angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('AppController',
    function($scope) {
      $scope.time = new Date();
    }
  );

Template


<div ng-controller="AppController" >
  <p>{{time}}</p>
</div>

Final result


<div ng-controller="AppController" >
  <p>{{time}}</p>
</div>

Let's add some functionality to scope and show off data binding.

The $interval service executes a function on scope in the supplied interval.


angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('TimeController',
    function($scope, $interval) {
      // Set the value of $scope.time to 'now' every 10 ms
      $interval(function() {
        $scope.time = new Date();
      }, 10);
    }
  );
  


<div ng-controller="TimeController">
  <p>{{time}}</p>
</div>

{{time}}

There's no magic happening here.

This demonstrates how changes on scope are reflected in the view once the DOM has been compiled and linked by Angular.

controller as

Although we've demonstrated setting up controllers with the ngController directive, and using $scope, there is a second (and preferred) method of declaring controllers.

This is commonly known as controller as syntax.

When we first declared a controller without using controller as, it looked like this:

Controller


angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('TimeController',
    function($scope, $interval) {
      // Set the value of $scope.time to 'now' every 10 ms
      $interval(function() {
        $scope.time = new Date();
      }, 10);
    }
  );

Template


<div ng-controller="TimeController">
  <p>{{time}}</p>
</div>

Now, note the changes in the controller and the template when we use the controller as syntax:

Controller


angular.module('app.controllers', [])
  .controller('TimeController',
    function($interval) {
      var vm = this;
      // Set the value of vm.time to 'now' every 10 ms
      $interval(function() {
        vm.time = new Date();
      }, 10);
    }
  );
  


<div ng-controller="TimeController as timeCtrl">
  <p>{{timeCtrl.time}}</p>
</div>

{{timeCtrl.time}}

We'll be using the controller as syntax in all of the labs you'll be working on later.

Bootstrapping

Angular initializes automatically upon DOMContentLoaded event or when the angular.js script is evaluated if at that time document.readyState is set to 'complete'.

At this point Angular looks for the ng-app directive which designates your application root.

Typically the ng-app directive is used on the root html or body elements so that the entire document is traversed and linked by the compiler.



<html ng-app="app">

</html>
